answers.answer: The main thing would be to make sure that the diagnosis of a "rare form of pneumonia" has been correctly diagnosed and is being treated appropriately with the best medicine available.  You should request that she be seen in consultation by an Infectious disease specialist, if she has not already been seen.The combination of diabetes, heart failure, respiratory failure and kidney failure, with pneumonia and failure of her white blood count to come down, in response to therapy, is very worrisome and, with that many things going on, she may not survive.That is out of your hands but what you can do is insist that she be seen and cared for by the best doctors available, for her multiple conditions.You might ask her doctors if her kidney failure is acute and possibly related to her unresponsive lung infection or if it is chronic and on the basis of the diabetes.  The latter would be more ominous.  Also ask if they have, with some degree of certainty, identified the cause of her pneumonia.  If not, what else could be done to make an accurate diagnosis?Is her breathing on the respirator being supervised by a doctor with expertise in such treatment:  a pulmonologist or a critical care specialist?Finally, you should ask which doctor is in charge of her care and then ask that doctor for his/her frank opinion about her likelihood of survival and if she is getting all the available, necessary care required, if she is to have a chance to survive.Good luck.

question: My mom of age 68 went in to the hospital on Aug 15 for an infected toe due to her diabetes.  Since the amputation of her toe, she has received a leg bypass, which opened the blood flow down to her foot.  She has many medical problems diabetes, hypertension, high blood pressure, conjestive heart failure, and since in the hospital starting on dialysis.  Our main problem is that she has been diagnos with a rare form of pnemonia.  They have been giving her lots of anitbotics but nothing seems to work.  Her white blood count is high.  She is intubated and they are feeding her thru nose.  She was off the intubator but when trying to put a new catheter she went into respertory arrest and intubated her again.  What questions should I be asking the doctors and what test would you recommend should be done.  My family and I are becoming less optomistic but haven't lost hope.  Any help would be greatly appreciated.  Thank You!
title: What questions to ask?
